talk.start.para: - I present From 87 citizens of the State of Tasmania the following petition:

quote.para: To the Honourable the President and members ot the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
Thai due to the higher living cost, persons on social service pensions are finding it extremely difficult to live in even the most frugal way.

- I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. What form of control is exercised over local and overseas manufactured sun glasses in relation to the standard of eye protection? Did the States act in conjunction with the Commonwealth to enforce standards which are based on the filtering properties of such glasses as a result of a complaint J lodged last year concerning the rejection by the armed forces of the United States of America >( Australian made sun glasses because of their inferior quality? - I recall the interest which Senator Mulvihill expressed in this matter previously. [ have some information for him concerning the points he has raised today. First of all. he asked what form of control there was of standards for the production of sun glasses, both locally and overseas. The answer I have in relation to that question is none - (here is no form of control. The answer to his second question is that no standards exist in respect of sun glasses for general public wear. - I seek clarification from the Minister representing the Treasurer in respect of financial assistance to the States for drought relief. Is it so, as was reported in the Adelaide 'Advertiser' recently, that no State is eligible for assistance until it has expended Si. 5m of its own resources on drought relief in that State?

speech.para: Senator Sir KENNETHANDERSONI recall that Senator Laucke asked me a question on this matter last week. I replied then that the normal procedure in relation to drought relief was not so much a matter for the Treasurer as a matter on the Premier to Prime Minister level in the first instance. There was reference to the fact that South Australia was required to find $1.5m as a preliminary to assistance being given by the Commonwealth. However, it would be wrong to assume, as I understand certain of the media have assumed, that the $1.5m is the start line for every State. For example, New South Wales was required to find $4m before the Commonwealth considered that it should intervene following a calamity which went beyond the responsibility or financial capacity of the State. The SI. 5m was regarded as being within the capacity of South Australia. It was considered - this is comparable, is it not? - that $4m was within the area which New South Wales could and should be able to provide to meet the situation. So if, as I understand the Press, it is suggesting that a blanket $l.5m is the starting line, it is quite wrong. The starting line would depend on the State; it would depend on the circumstances of the Stale, its geographical position and its economic capacity. In the case of New South Wales, the figure was not Si. 5m; it was $4m.

- The honourable senator's question relates to a broad economic issue, but he has nar rowed it down to one particular area. In answering questions from the honourable senator and other honourable senators before todayI have pointed out that the movement of the interest rate is an economic instrument. The Government exercised that economic instrument in relation to the trends of the economy which were prevalent at the time that it acted. I also recall that at the time I answered questions on this matter I pointed out that movement of the interest rate is not something that has been dreamed up or cooked up in Australia. It is a recognised economic instrument all over the world.

- On the contrary. In some instances it can be easily demonstrated to have saved the economy. A notable example occurred in the United Kingdom. Senator Murphy has picked out the application of the exercise to one particular industry in isolation, and has sought to use it as an argument against the basic concept. Quite frankly, it is not a valid argument.

answer.para: I think the Minister for Housing in the last few weeks has fully and effectively answered such arguments. She has demonstrated that whilst at certain stages commencements in the housing field have slowed down - if honourable senators opposite want the Minister to give the details again, I am sure she will do so - there has been again quite a significant movement in the number of commencements in the housing industry. I reject the suggestion of Senator Murphy that it is possible to take something which covers the whole Australian economy and is introduced for the benefit of the whole Australian community, then choose from it one particular item and say, because that item does not respond as quickly as others, that the application of the instrument was wrong. It is a fallacious argument.

talk.start.para: - Senator Murphy in this question has perpetuated the fallacy that was contained in his previous question. Apparently he thinks that he and I should conduct a debate on this subject at question time, lt pays a poor compliment to other honourable senators who wish to ask questions. I invite the honourable senator to study the history of previous United Kingdom Governments. In any free country in the world he can find a demonstration of how the interest rate has been operated and varied in accordance with the economic problems affecting the whole nation at the time. - There is no doubt in my mind, and probably there is no doubt in the minds of all honourable senators on this side of the chamber, of the Australian Democratic Labor Party, and perhaps to a degree of honourable senators opposite, that Australia will not be intimidated by any nation in the world. talk.start.para: - On 29th September 1970, Senator O'Byrne asked me a question without notice concerning increases in consumer prices. I indicated I would refer the question to the Treasurer. The Treasurer has supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

question.para: The consumer price index was 3.5 per cent higher in the second half of 1969-70 than in the second half of 1968-69. Over the same period, the index for the food group increased by 3.1 per cent. Within the period there was an accelerating tendency; the total index rose at an annual rate of 4.2 per cent between the first and second halves of 1969-70, while the annual rate of increase for the food group index was 4.8 per cent.

These high rates of increase are largely a reflection of inflationary tendencies on the wage side evident throughout 1969-70 together with mounting pressures of demand until late in the year. The Government has acted, through fiscal and monetary policies, to curb excessive demand pressures, and the success of these policies has been evident in an easing tendency in the very tight labour market. Experience suggests, however, that there is an appreciable lag before an easing trend in consumer prices. Meanwhile, upward pressures on costs emanating from very large increases in wages are continuing; average earnings increased by 9.0 per cent in the year to the June quarter, and increases of this magnitude, being far in advance of the rate of growth in productivity, must be reflected in substantial increases in unit costs and, ultimately, in consumer prices.

In the particular matter of the prices of foodstuffs, there are numerous influences at work in addition to the general economic factors mentioned above. In particular, supply considerations play a big part in short-term price movements. Drought conditions, for example, were a major factor in the sharp increases in food prices between 1965-66 and 1967-68. Thereafter, until recently, food prices rose less rapidly than prices in general.

As for methods of stabilising prices, the Government's most effective contribution to this end lies in following sound and responsiblefiscal and monetary policies directed, in an overall sense, to keeping the level of demand in the economy rising adequately but not excessively. In respect of rising costs, the Government exercises its limited influence as best it can, but there is a need for general community awareness that excessive demands, whether on employers, customers or even governments, can only tend to perpetuate inflation.

asked how the concession of 400 gallons a year for home wine makers had been arrived at. The Government acknowledges that home wine production is of real meaning to migrant family groups, and traditional freedom is allowed to them in this country. Further, the concession assists in the absorption of the wine grape crop. The Government decided that the concession was appropriate but it imposed very strict conditions that none could be sold, otherwise all of the wine would be excisable. Determination of the upper limit of 400 gallons is based upon what is considered to be a reasonable consumption quantity for traditional home wine producing family groups, not only for single families. It is thought that in a family group someone will be the head wine maker and that he will produce the wine and the whole family group will drink it. Groups of families band together in cooperative schemes, and 400 gallons a year spread over 5, 6 or 7 families is certainly not an excessive concession. If sales tax had been imposed instead of an excise any wine made for home use and not for sale would have been exempted so, therefore, in a sales tax situation a concession still would have been available.

In the 1950s, when I was in the other House, in one of my very early speeches in Parliament - in fact, it was almost 20 years ago - at page 1495 of Hansard of 26th October 1950 I advised of the introduction in the House of Commons of a Bill for the purpose of providing for the rehabilitation and re-establishment of disabled citizens. I give credit to the Government for introducing this legislation, as far as it goes, but 1 hope the Minister will heed our requests. On behalf of the Australian Labor Party, as I mentioned at the outset of my remarks, we intend to support the Bill.

speech.para: The general comments of honourable senators on diesel fuel have been listened to with some care. I think it has been acknowledged by honourable senators on both sides that diesel fuel for farm machinery is not subject to duty and that only 20 per cent of all diesel fuel is subject to duty. I have nothing further to add. This is a revenue raising exercise, as mentioned earlier, in the indirect tax field. The reason for raising the revenue is to apply it to the purposes outlined in the Commonwealth Budget.

Senator MURPHY

talk.start.para: - The Opposition is opposed to this Bill which is an ancillary to the other Bills. It is completely inflationary, and unnecessarily so. Along with the other measures proposed by the Government, it will cause a further bout of inflation. We see no justification whatever for it. We believe that the support of these measures by individuals on the Government side and members of the Australian Democratic Labor Patry, who are supporting the Government on this whole series of measures, brings no credit to them.

speech.para: It means that people have been speaking outside this chamber about protecting the family man, about protecting industry against inflation and about protecting the whole of the community, yet inside this chamber the Government is proposing measures which will injure the family man, injure industry and be bad for Australia and those measures are being supported by members of the Australian Country Party, who profess to be against this kind of thing, as well as by individual members of the Liberal Party, and they are also being supported by the members of the Democratic Labor Party who are present. We did not stop the passage of the Bill at every stage including the Committee stage, but we propose to vote against and to divide the Senate on this motion for the third reading.

talk.start.para: - I would not have spoken except for the kind reference that was made by Senator Murphy to the members of my Party. I thought that the election campaign was to open on the 28th of this month. It appears that it has opened here today. 1 have been listening to references to a whole series of measures for which the Australian Labor Party is taking great credit unto itself. What interests me is that the ALP is prepared to vote against the Budget to save the wine drinkers and it is prepared to vote against the Budget to save the tobacco smokers, but it did not vote against the Budget for the sake of the pensioners. All it moved in the case of the pensioners was a mild and gentle rebuke of the Government.

speech.para: What I wonder is: What does the tobacco industry have, what does the wine industry have and what do all these other industries have that the pensioners do not have? If a Labor government were in office I would expect the Labor Party to go to the barricades for the pensioners. But in this case the pensioners run about tenth in the field. There were 9 or more other issues on which the Labor Party thought it was advisable to vote against the Budget, but the pensioners were left for dead. One could not have shot them with a rifle because they were so far down the field.

What is being said by the ALP is that we should vote against this and this and this. We have already taken action in regard to the receipts tax. The Government has to supply another$80m. We suggested that the taxation reductions that were made should not have been made and that that money should have been used for the pensioners and all the other good people. But we did not receive any support from the Australian Labor Party. Its trade union supporters demanded the tax cuts. So, we did not. receive any support on those issues. We are supposed to be a bit responsible.If we defeated all the measures that the ALP wants to defeat, the Government would not have enough money to pay the parliamentary salaries. I can understand why some honourable senators have become so white-faced. I hope that we are acting a little more responsibly. As I have said, we have all been in this game for a long time. I do not mind Senator Murphy doing a little bit of Senate electioneering.

talk.start.para: - I would not have entered this debate had it not been for the favourable remarks of Senator McManus of the Democratic Labor Party who can see some ulterior motive in the action of the Labor Party on this question. 1 think the attitude of the Australian Labor Party has been made quite clear. In speaking to the amendments every Labor Party speaker has condemned the small increases that were granted to pensioners and has agreed that the increase granted to pensioners was not enough. The question on which we voted in relation to pensions was whether the payment of increased pensions would be approved. No-one has suggested the pensioners have been given a fair deal. On every possible occasion members of the Australian Labor Party have criticised the Government for creating and preserving pockets of poverty throughout Australia. Tt has been suggested that there has been an attempt to use these taxation measures for election purposes, but I suggest that the plight of pensioners will be one of the main issues in the Senate election campaign. We recognise that there is a need for an additional payment to pensioners and for help in other areas of poverty throughout Australia.

speech.para: Senator McManussuggested that if we oppose all taxation there will not be enough revenue to enable the Government to pay the politicians. Our proposal is that there should be a readjustment of taxation. Although we were not opposed to a reduction in income tax if an increase was given to pensioners, we believe that there should be a rearrangement of taxation schedules so that the tax reduction will be more equitable than that proposed in the Budget. The suggestion is that we are opposing these measures for electioneering purposes, but. as Senator Murphy has said, every individual member of this Senate has had an opportunity to vote against each item in these measures and many have refused to do so. It has been said that we are in favour of wine drinkers. We are much concerned with the wine industry in South Australia and New South Wales.

talk.start.para: - I also enter this debate because T interpret Senator McManus' remarks as a challenge to members of the Australian Labor Party. For the last 5 years I have listened to members of the Democratic Labor Party arguing that the Australian Labor Party was obsessed with some limited social questions relating to pensioners and that we acted as though we were still living in the 1920s. Honourable senators opposite talk about liberty and people on the streets acting against the law, but the whole problem is that the Budget has been made into a mockery by the middle man who has been raking off his profits. Senator Cavanagh and other Opposition senators have dealt adequately with the wine industry. Because a person receiving an average income enjoys the so-called luxury of being able to purchase a bottle of wine, it does not mean that he is living it up. Government supporters have argued about the trade union movement and its attempt to gain better conditions, but the Government's Attorney-General's Department does not have the courage to prosecute Cahills Restaurants and other similar businesses because of their activities and because they bludge on the community. Senator Greenwood who is now trying to interject is a protagonist of big business, as he proved the other night in the debate on the Lighthouses Bill. The Government expects respect of law and order, yet it increases taxation in this way.

speech.para: In the case of the wine industry every bottle of wine will attract a further 5c in excise. Honourable senators opposite talk about helping primary industry, but they do nothing about the profiteering by big business in this instance. A similar situation applies in regard to the tobacco industry. I am a non-smoker, but surely to goodness no-one would deny to the trade unionist who works in the foundry the right to have a cigarette at lunch time. Yet the trade unionist, who is eulogised by Government supporters, will have to pay more for his cigarette. It is not of much use the Australian Council of Trade Unions securing wage increases because inevitably there follows the erosion of those increases by means such as those exemplified in this Budget.

Coming back to the reference by Senator McManus, he knows that the only way to solve the social welfare problem is through the concept of a national welfare scheme. During the campaign for the last House of Representatives election we propounded this concept and that is why we gained 17 seats. This is why in the next Senate election when we go out on to the hustings we will be condemning the Gorton Government for failing to do anything worth while. The Government has flunked the situation with regard to health and it has flunked it also in relation to medical services. Government supporters cry crocodile tears about the equity of members of the Australian Medical Association, but what happens when an individual is diddled out of his equity in the hospital and medical funds? There is nothing in the Commonwealth health regulations about consumer protection.

debate.para: Debate resumed from 15 October (vide page 1 1 68), on motion by Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin:

quote.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: - The Australian Labor Party supports this Bill. The Sheltered Employment (Assistance) Act was first introduced in 1967 by the Government which deserves much credit for it. Like the Minister for Social Services (Mr Wentworth), I pay tribute to the voluntary organisations which commenced sheltered workshops back in the early 1950s in order to help handicapped persons in our community. As we know, much progress has been made since that time. This Bill extends the 1967 Sheltered Employment (Assistance) Act in 3 ways. Firstly, it extends the $2 for $1 subsidy towards the capital cost of accommodation for disabled persons in normal industry. Secondly, it provides for a training fee of $500 to be paid to a sheltered workshop organisation where a former employee who is disabled to the extent required for invalid pension purposes graduates to normal employment and is able to retain such employment for a period of 12 months. Thirdly, it provides payment of a $1 for $1 subsidy towards the salary costs incurred by sheltered workshop organisations in the employment of persons to provide special supervision, medical guidance, counselling, social work or other services for their disabled workers in accordance with the final provisions contained in the Bill.

speech.para: This is a most commendable proposal and it meets with the support of parliamentarians and organisations assisting the handicapped throughout Australia. Like many other honourable senators, I have seen the tremendous grit and determination of men and women in sheltered workshops. Centre Industries in New South Wales is one of the advanced establishments in this field. I know that many honourable senators have visited sheltered workshops in their own States. I have had the privilege of seeing some of them and in particular I have seen that of Centre Industries. Like others who have seen that establishment, I returned from that visit feeling a very humble person. I saw courageous people of both sexes, many with little movement in their limbs or body, working on machines and producing goods which are sold on the competitive market. Every credit must be given to them and to the organisations and other people associated with the tremendous work and activity of these unfortunate people. I have with me a copy of the brochure given to people who attend Centre Industries. We who are physically able to work in industry and other fields must feel very humble when we look at the photos in this brochure of the people doing this work.

I am pleased to know, Mr Deputy President, that the trade union movement is assisting and co-operating in this work. It is of the utmost importance that governments and trade unions be ever watchful to see that no-one in these workshops is ever used as cheap labour or is ever exploited. These unfortunate people must not be exploited in any way. now or in the future. I am pleased to say that in the more than 100 sheltered workshops which now employ about 4,206 handicapped people, according to the June statistics, no-one is being exploited. Exploitation does not exist but I feel that this matter must be watched very carefully.

Thre are several aspects of this Bill which I and my Party would like to see extended. This matter must be approached with sympathy and understanding. While appreciating the rights now given to invalid pensioners to earn $10 a week under the tapered means test, I feel there is an injustice in that when any amount earned - I say, earned the hard way because I have seen how some of these unfortunate people earn their money- over and above $10 in a sheltered workshop the pension is reduced at the rate of 50c for every $1. That is what happens at the moment. A single invalid pensioner who receives $15.50 a week - the full pension without supplementary allowance - is allowed to earn a maximim of only $10 a week before the means test operates. This means that the total amount that can be earned is $25.50. A married invalid pensioner couple without children receive $27.50 a week but less if the wife is in receipt of a wife's allowance. They can earn $17, making a total of $44.50 before the means test applies. This has to keep 2 people. We must remember that these people have to live. They have to feed and clothe themselves and to pay board and lodgings.

The Opposition asks for the abolition of the means test for those employed in sheltered workshops. We ask that this Bill be amended in that way. We hope the Minister will heed our request in this respect. The Australian Labor Party, when it becomes the Government, will go further than this so far as the abolition of the means test is concerned. However, at present we are asking only that the Bill be adjusted in this way. Surely this small added incentive could be given to these people. It would cost little but would mean a great deal. According to the figures of the Commonwealth Bureau of Census and Statistics for the period ending in June, there were 133,766 people in receipt of invalid pensions. Only 4,206 were employed in sheltered workshops and very, very few of them received anything like $10 a week. This is not a new approach. I ask the Minister to adopt the same policy for accepted or recognised employees in sheltered workshops as that adopted in respect of blind workers; that is to abolish the means test. It has been said that ex-servicemen are not subject to the means test in certain respects.

talk.start.para: - By the very nature of a measure such as this incidents and anomalies occur, all of which seem to be crying out for some form of rectification. So it is only natural that, when Senator Fitzgerald rose to indicate support of the measure before the Senate tonight, he would find, as we all find, areas in which we feel a Government measure of this kind might be extended in order to render not only further aid but also aid that is peculiar and necessary to a particular group of handicapped people. Neverthless, I think it should be said that, when the Minister for Housing (Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin) presented this Bill to the Senate and made her second reading speech, in substance it represented yet another progressive step in dealing with the issues - whether they be social, vocational or economic issues - that arise and live in the world of handicapped people. I use the word 'progressive' advisedly. Honourable senators will recall receiving from the Department of Social Services a book which referred to the developments in social services over a fair period of time- from 1949 to 1970. The book referred to the implementation of the Sheltered Employment (Assistance) Act in May 1967. When it was introduced it enabled subsidies to be paid to churches, approved voluntary welfare organisations and local governing bodies towards the cost of new sheltered workshops, extensions or alterations to existing workshops or rental for 3 years where rented premises were used to provide sheltered employment. A number of other phrases denoting assistance are used. The Bill now before us is yet a further step in general Government assistance to this area of need.

speech.para: Even as we talk about and discover fresh areas of need I do not think we should forget that, in an exercise of this kind, not only is the Government exerting a measure of considerable sympathy for those people who are at this kind of disadvantage but also it is standing with that fine and dedicated group of people to whom Senator Fitzgerald referred and who in one form or another either manage the organisations or care for disabled people in one manner or other. Therefore it is necessary for the Government to lay down certain criteria not only to ensure that its money is being well spent but also to ensure that those in the greatest need get the greatest assistance. In the sheltered workshop programme issued by the Department of Social Services there is a summary of the main requirements which organisations must meet or agree to meet before assistance will be provided. Amongst other things, the organisation should have proper management and a board of management which is representative of appropriate interests in the community. The organisation should have a full time manager or administrator. There are provisions for the payment to disabled workers according to the work which they perform, as well as a number of other provisions.

With this background we reach a situation tonight in which we have before us a Bill, the purpose of which is to extend and to make even more effective the Government's interest in and programme of assistance to sheltered workshops. Honourable senators will recall that there were 3 particular emphases in the Bill. One of them referred to a subsidy towards the capital cost of accommodation for disabled persons who were able to work in normal industry. A second referred to the payment of a training fee in respect to persons placed in normal employment by a sheltered workshop organisation. A third referred to the subsidising of the salaries of certain staff members who are engaged in sheltered workshop management activities, lt seems to' me that the developments which the Government has brought forward by way of this Bill not only meet the immediate needs as far as sheltered workshops are concerned but also provide - I think very wisely and 1 hope effectively - for the further steps which will ultimately have to be taken. The proposals which we have in front of us tonight will provide the starting point for the further measures which may become necessary in the future.
Honourable senators will recall that in her second reading speech the Minister for

Housing drew attention to the fact that the effectiveness at the Government's assistance could be gauged by the fact that the granting of assistance to more than 100 sheltered workshops employing an estimated 5,000 handicapped people has been approved. These workshops are now producing goods worth S5m a year. Government assistance to the extent of almost $5m has been granted to workshop organisations during the past 3 years. It may be argued thai this is a small sum when compared to the number of institutions throughout Australia. In this respect I think we must pay tribute to the organisations involved in the field of sheltered workshops which have contributed $2m towards the cost of running them. [ believe that we should all place on record our tribute to those people who work with the mentally handicapped for their sympathy, care, understanding and knowledge of the physically and intellectually handicapped in the work which they do and for the interest which they take in the sheltered workshops and the concern which they express on behalf of handicapped people.

The Bill which is now before the Senate represents not only, as 1 said earlier, a progressive stage in the care of mentally handicapped people but also, as I recall the Minister describing it, the second stage of Commonwealth assistance. The Bill is designed to provide aid in 3 specific areas in which financial help is needed. In doing so it recognises the community service which organisations are providing in this special and necessary field of assistance for disabled people. Having said that, I think it is important to refer for a few moments to what I will call the peculiar circumstances of sheltered workshops. I believe that in doing so not only will the Government's role at this point of time, as it is expressed in this Bill, be more appreciated but also, and more particularly, the change in and the increasing needs of the sheltered workshops will be better understood. Those who work in such workshops are people who cannot work in the ordinary way as we understand it. They cannot work in an ordinary office or factory. However, under the terms of the assistance which will be provided by this Bill, as well as the assistance which has already been provided, these people will have an opportunity to become not only productive members of the community but also people who are able to live lives that are satisfactory to themselves and certainly to those people to whom they belong. To the world of industry it may be said that sheltered workshops are something quite different. The members of a sheltered workshop may be described as a labour force which a telephone call can organise or as a permanent group looking for contract work. Honourable senators will be familiar with the magazine Impetus'. The superintendent of workshops of the Foundation of the Disabled, Mr John Mott, in the July issue of Impetus' summed up the people who work in the sheltered workshops in this way:

quote.para: They save ordinary factory managers from having to plan and supervise work; if they tell me what has to be done and hand me the bits and pieces they can forget about it until the delivery date for the completed job. Because contracts are carried out on our premises, it saves outside factory space that can be diverted to other production. All our workers are trained and some of the intellectually handicapped people do a better job on tedious repetitive work than normal people. By being on immediate call we often provide a customer with a means of getting a high quality job done on work that may be uneconomical in his own factory.

speech.para: While that may be true, I think I should say at the same time that sheltered workshops must never be considered in any way whatsoever as being a source of cheap labour nor should they ever be regarded as instrumentalities of price cutting. The workers in the sheltered workshops may be handicapped but the organisations which run them certainly are not. They compete on the open market. They meet the terms of their contracts and carry out their business in a proper way. The point is that sheltered workshops are not charities, although they may well be organised and operated by .what we regard as charitable organisations. As an officer of a sheltered workshop once commented, the only charity in them begins in the workshop and ends at the door. Outside it is business as usual. The normal standards have to be met and the normal contracts fulfilled in the ordinary way. That being the case, additional care must be given in order that the terms of business can be undertaken and the contracts fulfilled. Therefore the accommodation issue, as it is described in the Bill and for which the Bill provides, is a good step in the Government's progressive programme of assistance to these people.

Proper and suitable accommodation, arranged through the terms of the measure which is before us, is not only of great benefit to these people but also the knowledge that it exists and can be obtained and will continue to be available is surely a source of great comfort and security to the families of the handicapped people and those who have a personal concern for them as well as to the handicapped people themselves. The proposed amendment of section 9 of the Principal Act will mean that all existing and future subsidised hostels will be able to offer accommodation to eligible disabled persons regardless of whether they are working in a sheltered workshop or in normal employment. The second feature of the Bill refers to the payment of a training fee to a sheltered workshop organisation employing the . type of employee to whom I made reference at the beginning of my remarks. The third section of the Bill refers to the subsidising of the salaries of staff members who perform special roles, such as supervision, counselling, medical attention and other similar areas of activity.

I believe that the chief value of this programme of assistance is that it is a self help exercise. lt has been particularly designed to help people to help themselves so that they not only become productive members of our society but also, as I said earlier, feel a sense of dignity and a sense of satisfaction at being able to live a creative life and to respond to creative opportunities. This Bill does not provide all the answers to the problems nor do we yet know all the questions because this is an area which is changing in style and. I regret to say, need. It is also changing in terms of the fact that there seems to be an increasing number of people in our society who are disabled and require this kind of assistance. The increase in numbers is due to the fact that, unfortunately, more and more people are finding themselves disabled as a result of injury or an accident. Whilst the measure which is before the Senate tonight is a fine measure which is designed to help those people who are restricted in this way, I should point out that the Government as well as the people of Australia must never forget that the causes of accidents also have to be tackled. The Government must not only increase its research activities but also the people of
Australia must increase their concern about finding a means to preserve the precious elements of life as well as to help the shattered remains of a disabled life.

The Bill deals with measures to provide assistance for physically and mentally handicapped people, which is a description which we all understand. But it may be that in another context at some period of lime some consideration might be given to sheltered workshops for people who work more slowly than other people and who also take longer to do things than the rest of us but whose only cause of this is the fact that they are old and advanced in years. I have been reading that projects in the United States have been industrially and socially successful by drawing older people into the work force of the nation and into the productive world. The difficulty is that in older years people work at their own pace and at a slower pace which they can match with ability and with their own enthusiasm. This same area of response applies in the sphere of disabled people. But in dealing with the needs of the community the first and greatest needs must be met first.

Like other honourable senators in their various States 1 have been interested to read and see something of the work of sheltered workshops in my State of South Australia. All South Australian members will be familiar with Bedford Industries which run 2 workshops. The Mentally Retarded Children's Society runs 3 workshops at Unley, Brompton and Kent Town. A group known as the Heritage Sheltered Workshop operates at Mount Gambier and the well known Phoenix Society has its workshop at Torrensville. When the Minister has the opportunity of speaking on this Bill I would be pleased if she could obtain some further details of the declared South Australian segment of workshop premises and grants approved in 1969-70 as set out on page 37 of the Social Services Annual Report for 1969-70. This is a matter of personal and State interest and is added only as a comment in the discussion of the Bill.

I return to the measure which is before us and note with appreciation the publications which the Department of Social Services issues in the interest of sheltered workshops, not only by way of information but also to encourage us and to let us know exactly what the Government is doing in this sphere, lt is also pertinent to comment that the Government departments issue such fine publications as the National Fitness Report. If ever there was a challenge to the community of Australia to keep itself physically and nationally fit it is the volumes that are put out telling us not only what is being done and what is available but also calling to mind the terrible price people who are disabled pay and the great needs which those same people have. As I said at the beginning, the Government measure which is before the Senate tonight is one of a series of progressive steps dealing with this very urgent and changing problem. In commending the measure I ask the Government to take all possible steps to improve the services as the years go by, not only in the field of care but also in the field of prevention.

talk.start.para: - The rationale of the measure now before the Senate is substantially a display of solicitude for those unfortunate people who are handicapped in the community in one way or another. Over the years the implementation of this type of thinking in the extension of the services which have been provided is extremely commendable. I would be in the forefront of those commending the Government for the extension which is provided in this measure. But while I say that is the rationale of the provisions which we are discussing 1 think another aspect of the matter should receive some consideration. We are living in an increasingly material age, an age of increasing technology where very often it is the technocrat, rather impersonal and sometimes unsentimental, who is called upon to discharge many of the things in this society which make it viable and workable. In such a society it is quite possible that a person who because of physical or mental handicap is unable to match his or her pace to the pace of modern society soon finds himself completely socially discarded. When I say 'socially discarded' I do not mean socially discarded in any sense that they are treated with contempt but" that they are laid aside from the stream of social life. Nothing is more disastrous than for that to happen. It is bad enough when it happens by the ordinary process of years. Due to the onset of years and the approach of retiring age those who are interested and active in their work in the community find themselves placed on one side and so, very quickly, one finds an erosion of the will and desire to contribute. The ordinary recreations of leisure time no longer satisfy the demands of the person and one finds a physical, mental and social deterioration.

speech.para: Society is setting its face in many ways against that invevitable process. By training and re-training for the post-retirement period an attempt is being made socially to equip these people so that as retiring ages become earlier and sometimes people retire at the peak of their mental and physical powers they are then still equipped to discharge different though still valuable functions in the community. In this area of social concern we are dealing with those who have not had an opportunity by normal physical or mental endowmnent to make their contribution. Therefore they may discover at the very beginning of what could be their working life a situation which faces most people, at worst, at the conclusion of their working life and the period of their social contribution. Both these situations create severe economic problems in the community.

With the concept of the welfare state and the accent on government solicitude for those in their retirement, sickness and situations like that, an increasingly heavy burden is placed on the Budget, the taxpayer and the work force. If the area of dependence is to be unduly increased then there is going to be a limit on the capacity of the work force to sustain it and certainly to support it at an increasing level of benefit. Therefore it is most important that in areas where it is possible the work force be maintained and the period of dependence on the income of the community be reduced as far as possible consonant with a man having the opportunity of retirement and leisure should he wish. This Bill operates in that area. This is an attempt not only prompted by charity and solicitude for the unfortunate but also having the effect of keeping in the work force and bringing into the work force those who otherwise would not be participants. I think this is a most important social and economic consideration.

If I have read the Minister's second reading speech correctly these implications have not been spelt out specifically though, of course, they are implicit in the whole of the programme and the whole of the approach. I do not think any speaker whom I have heard has particularly concentrated on this aspect. We must concede that perhaps il is the less sentimental and the less appealing aspect of the whole programme and yet it is an extremely valuable one. After ali, nothing is more soul destroying to a person who is physically handicapped but adequately mentally endowed than to feel almost from the beginning of what could be a working life that he is dependent. As 1 say, in a society which is today becoming increasingly technological a handicapped person is going to find himself at an increasing disability if he cannot be embraced within it. Strangely enough the technological society may make possible the employment of these good people who otherwise in a nontechnological society may not bc employable. There are limits to the skills - physical to a lesser extent, mental to a greater extent - which can be commanded by those who are physically or mentally handicapped. In a society which is dependent on what we might call crude labour use - that is the use and application of physical energy only- -it may not be possible to engage and employ many of these people.

Because of the increasing sophistication of our industrial process, because there is a high level of automation and mechanisation, there are repetitive processes, perhaps simple processes, which are quite within the physical competence of those who otherwise would be unable to make a contribution. While these people if not employed could be the victims of the technological society, provided they are adequately trained the technological society could find accommodation for them whereas a simpler and more primitive society could not. Therefore, as we approach the passage of this Bill, let us welcome it as a further display by the Government - I am sure governments of all political complexions would follow this line and implement the legislation within the availability of our resources - of public solicitude which will have tremendous consequences in the personal, family and domestic lives of these people. Let us welcome it also as a demonstration by the Government of the contribution that these good people, properly trained, properly looked after, can make to the economic welfare of Australia, to enrich our society financially, in providing the very benefits which they are receiving, and in providing similar benefits for others. From all points of view this is a most important and most rewarding measure.

As far as 1 can see, the three heads of the provisions of this Bill do cover the practical situations that arise. First of all, there is the provision of capital assistance for the accommodation of those who are not actually working in sheltered workshops but are employed in private industry. We know that one of the great psychological factors in rehabilitation or in the psychological sustenance of people is to let them operate in an area of social and economic normality so that they feel as little as possible that they are different from other sections of the community. If a person is able to live in hostel accommodation but is able to be employed in private industry out of a sheltered workshop, surely that is not only a contribution to the economic life of the community but also is a tremendous psychological contribution to the person himself.

Of course, the training of these good people does bring certain problems in its wake in relation to the financing of the institutions, particularly when these institutions are non-governmental, non-public. As has been pointed out by the Minister, there is a loss to the skilled work force of trained workers. As these are commercial propositions they have to have a certain economic viability, and an attempt is being made here to recoup them when, having lost to private industry those whose skills they were able to provide they have to train new workers. Thirdly, there is a provision relating to the need to have particular counsellors and particular teachers to bring these handicapped people to the level of employable skill.

For all these reasons this is a heart warming measure. Ultimately we will look at the consequences of these provisions from the standpoint of the economic contribution they make to the nation and to the welfare of the individual who will be the recipient of the benefits. The Australian Labor Party has very much pleasure in supporting this measure and commends the Minister and the Government for further extending the provisions of this type of legislation.

talk.start.para: - Senator Fitzgerald has indicated that the Australian Labor Party offers no opposition to this amending Bill. He has outlined ways in which it could be improved. I know that the Minister for Housing (Senator Dame Annabelle Ranking) will take into consideration the thoughts that Senator Fitzgerald has expressed when discussing this matter with the Minister for Social Services (Mr Wentworth). I believe we have come a long way in rehabilitation of the disabled. If we trace its history we find that prior to 1954 rehabilitation was carried out in the most scattered areas, with no concerted effort. Since that time there has been a remarkable improvement. I like to believe that it is as a result of the International Labour Organisation discussing this important matter at its assembly in 1954. At that conference the Organisation laid down guidelines for the world as to what should happen in this field.

speech.para: The Commonwealth Department of Social Services has played its part remarkably well in all States. But there are people of public spirit who have taken unto themselves the task of doing something about this problem in a private capacity. People in Australia should pay a great tribute to those people. I am proud to be associated with an organisation concerned with the establishment of a sheltered workshop which hopes to raise a quarter of a million dollars to build premises at Eagle Farm. This is typical of what goes on throughout Australia. I repeat that 1 believe that impetus was given to the rehabilitation of the disabled as a result of the International Labour Organisation discussing and laying down a programme in 1954.

The amending Bill has three principal features, to two of which I do not desire to address myself except to say that I do not know - perhaps the Minister could indicate this - how many people who work in sheltered workshops will be taking advantage of the accommodation provisions of the legislation. One provision awards a sheltered workshop $500 should any person in that workshop return to industry after 6 months. [ believe this creates an anomalous position. It is all very well to say that a workshop may train a person for 6 months or longer and then he goes into industry. What is to be the situation where the same sheltered workshop has trained, or endeavoured to train, somebody for 3, 4 or 5 years but that person is just incapable of being trained to a state of efficiency which will enable him to go into private employment? 1 think the Minister will see the anomaly that arises. Perhaps the Government will consider extending the relevant benefit to cases to which 1 have just referred. I know that the amending Bill provides that the amount may be paid at the discretion of the Minister in a lot of cases. I trust - I believe - that the Minister will exercise his discretion in favour of the sheltered workshop.

Senator Davidsonreferred to the publication 'Impetus', and I also desire to refer to it. For the information of honourable senators 'Impetus' is Australia's magazine of manufacturing, an official publication of the Chamber of Manufactures of New South Wales. The following appears in the July 1970 issue of that publication:

quote.para: Rod Holmes is an executive with a big job. In himself he is a very little man indeed - running hot he barely measures four feet tall - but he has the support of some of the giants of Australian industry. Mr Holmes is in the electrical business in only a modest way, but his personal qualifications are formidable - as a student at East Sydney Technical College he topped the State 3 years in a row. But that's nol all: he is remarkable in one other way - nol one of his workers is complete in body and in brain.

Rod Holmes is production supervisor in a sheltered workshop, an industrial operation where mcn and women work without legs, without hands, without eyes or ears, sometimes without much mind, lt is also an industrial operation which delivers the goods. Rod Holmes and a handful of men like him see to that. Comparatively few businessmen know anything about sheltered workshops; fewer realise that they can often fill a valuable role iti increasing profitability and productivity in outside industry.

First, what is a sheltered workship? There are 99 of them in NSW; all of them nin as industrial undertakings rather than as charities. The workers in them are people who cannot work in an ordinary office or factory but in this way are given the opportunity to become productive members of the community.

speech.para: That is a fine tribute to Rod Holmes. II Rod Holmes were here I think he would say that he is only one of many people doing a similar job for the disabled in Australia. We should pay great tribute to those people who have banded together in an endeavour to help the less fortunate in life. For that reason I was a little disturbed at the following" passage in the second reading speech of the Minister for Housing who in this place represents the Minister for Social Services:

quote.para: A considerable amount of lime is spent by many sheltered workshops training their disabled employees until they reach a degree of proficiency which enables them lo accept outside employment. Sheltered workshops are, therefore, continually losing their most proficient workers with resultant loss of their productive capacity.

speech.para: I direct the attention of the Senate to the sentence which followed:

quote.para: Because of this there has been an understandable reluctance on the pan of . many workshops to encourage their best workers to attempt the step to open employment.

speech.para: I quarrel with that statement of the Minister. I am sorry to have to throw such a quarrelsome note into this debate because there is unanimity of thought on the measure. Nevertheless it was an unfortunate choice of words by the Minister. In effect he said that Rod Holmes and the thousands of other people throughout Australia who are interested in the rehabilitation of the disabled prevent their good workers from going into outside industry notwithstanding the fact that they are capable of doing so. He is saying, in effect, that the sheltered workshop is denying the good worker in that shop the opportunity to go into private industry and to make a living wage because no sheltered workshop can afford to pay a real living wage to its inmates. As I have said, it was unfortunate that the Minister chose those words. Following the Minister's statement I raised the matter by way of question to the Minister for Housing as representative in this place of the Minister for Social Services. On 14th October 1970 the Minister for Social Services replied to me as follows: 1 refer to the question without notice which you addressed to the Minister for Housing, Senator the Hon. Dame Annabelle Rankin, on \1 September, referring to my second reading speech on the Sheltered Employment (Assistance) Bill 1970, and asking whether you could be supplied with the names of the sheltered workshops which I stated showed an understandable reluctance to encourage their best workers to graduate to open employment. information about the activities of approved sheltered workshops is obtained by my Department as the result an annual survey.

When these surveys were instituted some organisations, as independent business enterprises, were reluctant to make available detailed information concerning their commercial activities and policies. Because of this they were assured that the data provided by individual workshops would be treated as confidential, and that any published information would not identify particular workshops. A copy of the 1969 survey report is enclosed.
You will appreciate that, in the circumstances, the disclosure of information of the kind sought would bc regarded as a breach of confidence on my part.

I do not believe that that information can be regarded as confidential. The Minister has said that there is some reluctance on the part of sheltered workshops to pass out into private industry some of their good workers. I have had substantial experience with sheltered workshops and organisations of that nature, and I know of no organisation which would do that to a person whom it has rehabilitated. In those circumstances I take strong exception to the Minister's words and regard his answer as completely unsatisfactory.

I conclude by saying that whenever I walk into a sheltered workshop I feel rather sympathetic but encouraged - sympathetic when I think that there are people in the world today who by an accident of birth or as a result of some other misfortune are forced to go into those organisations: encouraged because of the fortitude that they display in trying to overcome their difficulties, and also by reason of the fact that there are so many people in Australia who willingly give of their time to assist those unfortunate people. The Australian Labor Party supports the principles of the Bill but I have indicated one clause which I believe will throw up some anomalies and I ask the Minister to have that clause reviewed.

talk.start.para: - Does that mean that no Commonwealth grant is made to a State for that purpose?

- I should like to address myself to an answer given by the Minister for Housing (Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin) in reply to one of my questions. First I refer to the definitions contained in proposed sections 16a and 16b. If 1 correctly interpreted the Minister's remarks, she said that, if a sheltered workshop trained a person for not less than 6 months and if the trained person stayed in the workshop for 12 months, the workshop would receive the training fee of $500. I am afraid that my understanding of the Bill does not coincide with that interpretation. Proposed section 16a states:

quote.para: In this Part, 'normal employment', in relation to a person, means:

item.label: (a)

speech.para: I do not worry about sub-section (b) at this stage. Then we come to proposed section 16b which states: (1.) Where:

item.label: (a)
item.para: a disabled person who has completed a continuous period of nol less than 6 months' sheltered employment provided by an eligible organisation completes, on or after the commencement of this Part, a further continuous period of 12 months' normal employment;

speech.para: I draw to the Minister's attention the definition of 'normal employment' and contrast it with the interpretation that I believe she placed on my earlier remarks. I should like some explanation of that.

- I am sorry to be per sistent about this, but there are just 3 words that the Minister omitted and I would need those 3 words for her answer to be clear to me. Does the person working in a sheltered workshop have to receive the award wage for that class of work before the sheltered workshop qualifies for the $5007

debate.para: Bill (on motion by Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 15 October (vide page1 169), on motion by Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin:

quote.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: - In due course the Australian Labor Party proposes to move an amendment to this Bill. We believe it is deficient in 2 aspects. Firstly, it fails to provide adequate grants to the States in terms of the finance that is being made available in the Budget for 1970-71, namely, $5m. Secondly, it is deficient because it simply continues to extend a provision introduced in 1955 as a consequence of an extensive and meticulous examination of mental health facilities and the needs of Australia in that field, a report on which was tabled at that time at the request, I presume, of Sir Earle Page, who was then Minister for Health. The report recommended among other things financial assistance to the States to enable them to bring up to modem day requirements the institutions that were obviously in a shocking, deplorable and dilapidated state. The report also recommended that finance be made available for additional buildings and equipment on the basis of Si to be paid by the Commonwealth for every $2 provided by the States.

speech.para: We believe that the Bill is also deficient in that it has failed to adopt a number of recommendations in what is referred to as the 'Stoller report'. That report recommended what can best be described as the development of a regional community and integrated mental health service' for those people who are mentally retarded, mentally disturbed and intellectually retarded. I think it is essential at this stage to refer briefly to the second reading speech of the Minister for Housing (Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin), who in this chamber represents the Minister for Health (Dr Forbes). She pointed out that the Bill extends the operation of the States Grants (Mental Health Institutions) Act 1964-67 only for a further period of 3 years, from 1st July 1970 to 30th June 1973.

The Minister went on to point out that the basis of the grant would be the same as the previous basis, namely, $1 for every $2 expended by the States. She restated on behalf of the Minister for Health that this Bill applies only to mental institutions as described, and its provisions are confined to the construction and alteration of buildings used for the purpose specified, and the acquisition of equipment for use in mental health institutions. In another place the Minister for Health, speaking in the debate on an amendment proposed by (he Opposition to this Bill, said, as reported at page 2245 of Hansard of the current sessional period:

quote.para: Admittedly, and to be fair, t must say that the State governments have asked the Commonwealth for more in fact than we have given in this field.

speech.para: The Minister acknowledged a deficiency in terms of the amount of money to be made available to the States for mental health institutions, as provided for in this Budget, namely, S5m. The Minister challenged the propriety of the Opposition in moving its amendment. At page 2246 of Hansard he is reported to have queried, in the following terms, the Opposition's right to propose its amendment:

quote.para: I regard the Opposition amendment as another attempt by honourable members opposite, sitting in their ivory tower in Canberra, to tell the States what is good for them, how to run their mental health services, to intrude their judgment gained at second hand or through reading material written by someone else, into matters which are clearly the responsibility of the States.

speech.para: I want to deal with that aspect because I believe that the Government has been sadly remiss in discarding or setting aside the many recommendations contained in the Stoller report. 1 think I should refer briefly to the commission that was extended to Dr Stoller in 1955 by the then Minister for Health. I think it is appropriate to refer briefly to the foreword to the report, by Sir Earle Page, who said:

quote.para: This report by Dr Stoller assisted by Mr Arscott on the mental health facilities and needs of Australia is the first full Australian appreciation of the position of the treatment of mental disease.

The Commonwealth Government desired such an appreciation of the whole position to ensure a properly informed discussion with the Slate governments on the best methods of co-operation in this field. . . .

The Commonwealth Government felt that a full picture of mental disease and its treatment was imperative as a preliminary to discussion with the State governments. The States consented that Dr Stoller and Mr Arscott should have full access to their whole organisations. That full picture is given in their excellent and illuminating report, which has now been presented.

speech.para: With those words the then Minister for Health put beyond question the extent and excellence of the report. Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin in her second reading speech referred to the fact that $44m had been made available to the States since the original Act of 1955. I think we should bear in mind the deplorable state of the mental health services and institutions in ali States at that time. There was need for a massive sum of money simply to renovate institutions that had been standing for a very long time. Such institutions have been standing in the west and north west of Victoria, at Ararat and Beechworth, and in the metropolitan area at Kew, since 1867.

The sum of $44m has been provided over a period of 15 years, or at the rate of a shade less than $3m a year. As it has been spread over 6 States, the amount received by each State leaves a lot to be desired. Nevertheless, this money has materially assisted the States to raise the standards of mental health institutions and equipment that were in such a deplorable state. Quite apart from that contribution by the Commonwealth, a great range of services outside the identifiable institutions is essential for what Dr E. Cunningham Dax has referred to as a 'need to create an environment which is designed to rehabilitate all the mentally ill by returning them to the mainstream of the community'. I think this aim will bear some examination. Amongst other things, the Stoller report referred, at page 171. to research. I think the. reference is quite pertinent to the amendment I propose to move on behalf of the Opposition. Section E was headed Research' and the comment was:

quote.para: This is conspicuous by its absence - a fact which is not surprising when all mental health resources are being used to maintain the service which it is giving at present, inadequate as it is.

speech.para: Under subsection 5, 'Final Remarks', commencing on the same page, the Stoller report stated:

quote.para: It has been shown that there is much to be done to -

item.label: (a)
item.para: overcome years of neglect and inertia in mental hospitals, and

item.label: (b)
item.para: bring the standard of Australian psychiatry to a reasonable level of modern practice.

quote.para: Modern psychiatry is thought of, and practised, in relation to - (a)a service for sick people,

item.label: (b)
item.para: a service for some social welfare problems, and

item.label: (c)
item.para: in the preventive field, as a positive contributionto the total health of the community.

speech.para: The report went on to state:

quote.para: Throughout our tour, we have met with requests for psychiatric help in all these fields and regrets have been expressed, at many levels of society, that mental health needs are not being fulfilled.

speech.para: I repeat thatthis suggestion was made to the Commonwealth Government and to the then Minister for Health, Sir Earle Page, 15 years ago. The report continued:

quote.para: Any programme lo remedy matters must take into consideration -

item.para: The remedy of overcrowding in mental hospitals.
The improvements of medical standards in mental hospitals.
The provision of large numbers of suitablytrained professional staff.
An increase in community service, including early treatment, services, clinics, training centres, and community education.

A programme of applied and basic research. 1 think it fair to say that during the course of the last 15 years the Commonwealth Goverument has contributed towards alleviating, at least in part, much of the accommodation difficulties experienced in the years prior to that report. Notwithstanding that, insufficient attention has been directed towards providing suitably trained professional staff. Also, insufficient assistance has been given to community services, of which there are many, based on parent organisations and other interested persons who voluntarily give their time and energy in order to assist those less fortunate who suffer from some mental defect of varying degrees. These organisations do receive some form of assistance from State governments but it is rather an inconsistent sort of financial support. lt varies from State to State and is far from sufficient to enable them to provide the necessary services outside institutions to provide a stepping stone back into the community and the mainstream of social and economic life.

speech.para: The final suggestion of the Stoller report for a programme of applied and basic research would call for additional finance to enable psychologists, psychiatrists and similar people, required for therapeutic treatment, social work, psychiatric centres, and administrative and other stuff, to be employed. My studies of the position in Victoria reveal that this staff has been increased and I am sure that the situation is not dissimilar in other States. 1 think what I have said discounts the suggestion made by the Minister for Health in the other place that the Opposition is relying on people who have no connection or understanding of the situation in Australia. I repeat that the Stoller report was commissioned by the government of the day. Regrettably it is still the government of the day but f think it is only a matter of time before the Australian Labor Party becomes the government. We would act upon the substance of the suggestions made by Dr Stoller and his colleague. I want to refer to suggestions made by Dr Cunningham Dax, a man for whom I have very high personal regard. He was chairman of the newly constituted Mental Hygiene Authority in Victoria. I think it was created in about 1950 or 1952.

talk.start.para: - He is giving Tasmania the benefit of his wisdom now.

- 1 second the amendment. T support the amendment because it is in line with world thinking on the treatment of mental illnesses. I could refer to many of the surveys, examinations and investigations which have been made to show positively that regional development is absolutely essential in this field. Senator Brown referred briefly to the task force which was appointed by President Kennedy in the United States of America shortly after his election to the his august position. This task force took in the fields of law, accommodation and treatment. The reports which were submitted to the President by this task force showed quite clearly on every account that the old method of keeping the mentally ill had gone by the board and should be abolished and not bolstered up, as is happening in some of the States of the Commonwealth at present. The reports indicated that wherever possible a crash programme should be introduced to bring about a hospitalisation and treatment system on a regional basis which accommodated no more than 300 patients in each institution, lt would be quite obvious to anybody who has investigated this problem and visited these institutions that this is vitally necessary.

speech.para: In company with the honourable member for Burke (Mr Keith Johnson) in the other place I had the privilege of being shown through the Sunbury mental hospital by its superintendent. I have spoken before in this chamber on this matter. It absolutely horrified me to see mentally ill people living in the conditions under which they live in this institution. Old gaol-type buildings are being improved to accommodate the mentally ill people. The only answer T could, think of to the problem is for the Commonwealth Government to provide money on a much larger scale in the field of mental health so that some of the present institutions can be bulldozed down and new and improved facilities made available. No matter how dedicated the members of the staff of such institutions as Sunbury and Beechworth may be they cannot operate efficiently under the present conditions. Money is being spent on these institutions, but in most cases it is to no avail.

Some of the present institutions are cold, stone buildings; no heating system can be installed in them. We were horrified when the superintendent at Sunbury told us that he had to stand 8, 10 and sometimes 12 patients stark naked in a cold corridor during the middle of winter while they waited for their morning shower or bath. This is an example of the type of building which is in existence today. These institutions were established in the days when everybody thought that the way to treat mentally handicapped people was to put them in a gaol-like asylum and forget about them. The tragic thing is that this view was shared not only by the authorities but also by many parents who felt that it was a great disgrace to them to have a mentally afflicted child.

talk.start.para: - I do not propose to speak for very long on this measure. I think we should approach it, not in an atmosphere of panic, but in an atmosphere of common sense. Many of the comments which have been made about (he situation regarding mental illness arc true. I do not think we should endeavour to associate anybody with blame on the question because mental illness is almost a natural sequence of the way of life we lead and the medical knowledge which has really developed so rapidly in recent years. Probably it was the rapid development of medical knowledge of a physical character which, in the first place, when man discovered that the brain tissue does not heal as does the rest of the body tissue established a somewhat hopeless attitude towards mental illness. As far as the damaged section of the brain was concerned it was irrevocably destroyed. 1 think it was quite natural that an attitude that mental illness was somewhat of a hopeless character developed. So we persisted not with the treatment of mental illness but with the restraint of those who were likely to be dangerous to the rest of the community. Of course that altitude built up.

speech.para: In the beginning it was more the pity of those who were closely associated with the restraint of people who were mentally ill and suffering physically that redirected attention to the problem. Indeed scientists began to discover when dealing not so much in the physical but more in the psychological fields that there were causes other than actual brain damage for mental illness. There could be associated nervous situations which could create circumstances of mental illness and which had nothing to do with the physical damage to the brain itself. From this the idea was established that treatment was possible. This idea is of quite recent origin. So we reached the situation we arc in today where we are beginning to have recommended to us by many people different types of treatment. Those more associated with regional efforts have found that where patients can be kept closer their psychological reactions are less drastic than when separated from all the things they know and understand and from the people they have been associated with. They are given a sense of security on which to build the treatment of the illness.

Because of this we in the Australian Democratic Labor Party see nothing wrong with the Bill. We also see nothing wrong with the amendment. We feel that the amendment merely clarifies what is possible within the ramifications of the Bill. For that reason we are in favour of expressing the opinion that this financial assistance should be made available. 1 would counsel Senator Poyser not to be carried away too much by statistics which can be produced to show that one person in every three is suffering from some form of mental illness. It is quite probable that one person in every three in this Chamber if not suffering from some form of mental illness or psychlogical disturbance tonight is suffering from a physical illness of some form which their bodies will recover from completely and entirely without any medical assistance whatsoever. This is true in the physical sense and, to some extent, it is true in the mental sense that many people make their own adjustment to psychological ailments and disturbances with the assistance of those who are close to them and who help them in some small ways.

The quoting of mere statistics can perhaps throw the whole community into a panic. I know that some of the well trained people quote statistics to create just that situation because it is the only way to draw the attention of the whole community to something with which we all - never mind about our politics - naturally tend to put to one side and to feel that that is the problem of the other fellow who is individually concerned or whose family, in some way, becomes associated with the problem. I think we should approach the whole problem in an atmosphere of sympathy to each other and to the community as a whole, lt does not need me to tell honourable senators in this Chamber who are all probably acquainted with the problem of the tremendous advances that have been made in recent years particularly where the brain has been damaged by some natural sequence of life like the hardening of the arteries or the bursting of a tiny blood vessel in a small portion of the brain. Science has discovered that while it cannot heal the irrevocably damaged portion of the brain other portions of the brain can be trained to take over and perform the function of the injured portion.

A tremendous amount of work has been done in the field of geriatrics to help people who have been injured in this way. This is really a comparatively new field in which tremendous strides forward are being made. We feel that the other suggestions which have been put forward by trained personnel should be developed. They will not all be as successful as some of the progenitors of them hope but I think they offer a better deal to the whole community. In the final analysis another step forward will be taken in our general march to the better things in life for everybody. People will be helped to return to normality rather than be destroyed by the wrong type of physical restraint for a psychological or mental problem. Physical restraint was the old and natural form because of the knowledge of the times which did not permit anything else. People were driven further into the problem that they had and ultimately they became a complete charge upon the community. That is a waste. I do not think any of us like waste, whether it is of human capacity, human lives or human potential. For that reason alone when we begin to realise there is an opportunity to prevent this sort of human waste we are all for it.

My Party suggests that the amendment does not harm the Bill in any way. It could be considered that the Bill already makes some provision along these lines. If, in actual practice, this, to some extent has been done already, it does no harm whatever to direct specific attention to the growing need to place the financial capacity at the disposal of those who are in a position to bring real relief to the people concerned and to the nation. The Australian Democratic Labor Party supports the amendment.

talk.start.para: - This Bill is one of the few presented by the Government providing for increases in costs that the Australian Labor Party will not oppose. We support the Bill.
